Function.Description: You can use this function to parse a string looking for specific parts, which can then be replaced by the new string that you have specified in all places that they occur.
Function.Parameter: The string to be copied.
The substring within the string to be replaced in all instances.
The new substring to replace the previous one(s).

Function.Name: string_set_byte_at
Function.Description: This function sets a byte directly in a string (based on the UTF8 format) and returns a copy of the string with the changes.
Function.Parameter: The string to change the byte of.
The position within the string (starting at 1) to change the byte of.
The new byte value.

Function.Name: string_upper
Function.Description: With this function you can force a string to contain only upper case characters.
Function.Parameter: The string to convert to uppercase.

Function.Name: string_width
Function.Description: This function will return the width (in pixels) of the input string, taking into account any line-breaks the text may have. It is very handy for calculating distances between text elements based on the total width of the letters that make up the string as it would be drawn with draw_text() using the currently defined font.
Function.Parameter: The string to measure the width of.

Function.Name: string_width_ext
Function.Description: This function will return the maximum width (in pixels) of the input string, taking into account the line separation and line-break width (which is defined as the number of pixels that the string can occupy before a line break is inserted). It is very handy for calculating distances between text elements based on the maximum width of a string that is split over several lines as it would be drawn with draw_text_ext() using the currently defined font. Separation and width can be set to -1 to get the default spacing.
Function.Parameter: The string to measure the width of.
The distance in pixels between lines of text as if the string was being drawn.
The maximum width (in pixels) of the string before a line break as if the string was bring drawn.

Function.Name: string_ext
Function.Description: This function returns a new string using a format string with placeholder information and an array of values. The placeholders should follow the format "{x}" where x is the index of the value in the array that it should be replaced with.
Function.Parameter: The input string format.
An array of values to replace the placeholders.

Function.Name: string_trim_start
Function.Description: This function removes whitespace from the beginning of a string (left).
Function.Parameter: The input string.

Function.Name: string_trim_end
Function.Description: This function removes whitespace from the end of a string (right).
Function.Parameter: The input string.

Function.Name: string_trim
Function.Description: This function removes whitespace from both ends of a string and returns a new string, without modifying the original string.
Function.Parameter: The input string.

Function.Name: string_starts_with
Function.Description: This function determines whether a string begins with the characters of a specified string, returning true or false as appropriate.
Function.Parameter: The input string.
The string to check against.

Function.Name: string_ends_with
Function.Description: This function determines whether a string ends with the characters of a specified string, returning true or false as appropriate.
Function.Parameter: The input string.
The string to check against.

Function.Name: string_split
Function.Description: This function splits string into an ordered list of substrings by searching for the delimiter, puts these substrings into an array, and returns the array.
Function.Parameter: The input string.
The delimiter string to search for.
Removes empty entries from the output array.
The maximum number of splits that are allowed.

Function.Name: string_split_ext
Function.Description: This function splits string into an ordered list of substrings by searching from an array of delimiters, puts these substrings into an array, and returns the array.
Function.Parameter: The input string.
An array of delimiter strings to search for.
Removes empty entries from the output array.
The maximum number of splits that are allowed.

Function.Name: string_join
Function.Description: This function joins a set of arguments using the provided delimiter, non-string values will be converted to string.
Function.Parameter: The delimiter to use when joining the values.
The values be joined using the delimiter.

Function.Name: string_join_ext
Function.Description: This function joins the elements of an array using the provided delimiter, non-string values will be converted to string.
Function.Parameter: The delimiter to use when joining the values.
An array of values be joined using the delimiter.
The offset of the range (allows negative values, from end of string).
The number of elements to join (allows negative values, reverse traversing).

Function.Name: string_concat
Function.Description: This function concatenates a set of arguments, non-string values will be converted to string.
Function.Parameter: The values be concatenated.

Function.Name: string_concat_ext
Function.Description: This function concatenates a range of elements in an array, non-string values will be converted to string.
Function.Parameter: An array of values be concatenated.
The offset of the range (allows negative values, from end of string).
The number of elements to concatenate (allows negative values, reverse traversing).

Function.Name: string_foreach
Function.Description: This function iterates over each character of a string calling a provided function. It allows to specify a start position (1-based) and a length.
Function.Parameter: The string to iterate over.
A function to be called for each character in range (allows arguments 'char' and 'pos').
The position to start the iteration from (allows negative values, from end of string).
The number of iterations to execute (allows negative values, reverse traversing).

Function.Name: array_copy
Function.Description: With this function you can copy all or part of an array into another array at any position. You need to supply both the source and the destination arrays (both need to have been created previously), as well as a position within the source array to copy from and a position within the destination array to copy to. Finally you need to specify the length of the array (or the length of the part that you want) to copy. If the data being copied exceeds the length of the destination array, the array will be extended to accept the data.
Function.Parameter: The ID of the array to copy to.
The index within the array to copy to.
The ID of the array to copy from.
The index with the array to start copying from.
The length (number of array indices) to copy.

Function.Name: array_create
Function.Description: With this function you can create a 1D array of a given size. You tell the function the length of the array to create, and it will return the "handle" for the array which you can then assign to a variable. Arrays created in this way will have each entry initialised to 0 unless you specify an (optional) initialisation value. If you do supply the extra value for initialising the array, then all indices within the new array will be set to that instead of 0, but note that the function will have a greater performance overhead in this case.
Function.Parameter: The size of the array to create.
The value to use to initialise all array indices (optional).

Function.Name: array_delete
Function.Description: With this function you can delete a value (or values) from an array at any given position. The function requires you to provide a variable that holds the array, the index (position) in the array to delete from, as well as the number of values to delete.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The index (position) in the array to delete the value(s) from.
The number of values to delete.

Function.Name: array_equals
Function.Description: With this function you can check to see if two arrays are equal (equivalent or the same). You give the two arrays to check, and the function will return true if they are equal (either equivalent or the same) or false if they are not. Note that this is not the same as checking if two arrays are the same using ==, which will not check to see if the two arrays hold equivalent values, but only to see if the arrays are referencing the same initial array. For example:
Function.Parameter: The index of the first array.
The index of the second array.

Function.Name: array_get
Function.Description: With this function you can retrieve the value from an index in an array. The function requires you to provide a variable that holds the array and the index to get the value from within that array. Note that if the array index given is out of bounds then the game will crash with an error. This function can also be used for multi-dimension arrays, as long as you specify which dimension you want to get when you supply the array index, following this pattern:
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The index of the array to get the value from.

Function.Name: array_insert
Function.Description: With this function you can insert a value (or values) into an array at any given position. The function requires you to provide a variable that holds the array, the index (position) in the array to insert at, as well as at least one value to insert, although you can optionally provide further arguments and they will all be inserted into the array in consecutive order from the given index.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The index (position) in the array to insert the value(s)
The value to insert

Function.Name: array_length
Function.Description: With this function you can get the length (number of entries) of an array dimension. You supply the array index value and the function will return an integer value representing the number of entries the array contains. This function can also be used for multi-dimension arrays, as long as you specify which dimension you want to get the length of when you supply the array index, following this pattern:
Function.Parameter: The index of the array to check.

Function.Name: array_pop
Function.Description: With this function you can retrieve a value from the end of an array without having to know the length of the array. You supply the variable that holds the array, and the function will return the contents of last entry in the array. If the array is empty, the function will return undefined.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.

Function.Name: array_push
Function.Description: With this function you can push a value (or values) onto the end of an array without having to know the length of the array. The function requires you to provide a variable that holds the array as well as at least one value to push, although you can optionally provide further arguments and they will all be pushed onto the array in consecutive order.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The value to push onto the end of the array

Function.Name: array_resize
Function.Description: With this function you can resize an existing array dimension to a new size. You supply the array to be resized as well as the new number of indices for the array, and the function will resize that array. Note that this function is designed for resizing an array down to a smaller length as you can resize up by simply setting a new index in the array. That said, if you do use it to size up an array, any new indices will be set to the default value of 0.
Function.Parameter: The index of the array to resize.
The new size for the array (an integer, starting from 0).

Function.Name: array_set
Function.Description: With this function you can set the value of an index in an array to a value. The function requires you to provide a variable that holds the array as well as the index to set and the value to set it to. This function can also be used for multi-dimension arrays, as long as you specify which dimension you want to set when you supply the array index, following this pattern:
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The index of the array to set the value for.
The value to set.

Function.Name: array_sort
Function.Description: With this function you can sort an array in ascending order or descending order or using a custom function to define the sort order. The function requires you to provide the array to sort, and then either of the following:
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The sort type (true for ascending or false for descending) or a function reference to use for sorting.

Function.Name: array_shuffle
Function.Description: With this function you can shuffle an array (or subsection), a new array is returned that is a copy of the original with the entries shuffled.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The offset to be used when shuffling the array. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
How many entries should be shuffled. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_shuffle_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can shuffle an array (or subsection) in place, nothing is returned
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The offset to be used when shuffling the array. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
How many entries should be shuffled. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_get_index
Function.Description: This function returns the first index at which a given element can be found in the array (or subsection). If the value is not found the function returns -1.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The value to search for.
The offset to be used when searching the array. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
How many entries should be searched. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_contains
Function.Description: Determines whether an array includes a certain value among its entries, returning true or false as appropriate.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The value to check inside the array.
The offset to be used when looking through the array. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
How many entries should be checked. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_contains_ext
Function.Description: Determines whether an array includes certain values among its entries, returning true or false as appropriate. Doesn't account for order.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
An array of values to be search inside the provided array.
Whether the match should be complete of partial.
The offset to be used when looking through the array. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
How many entries should be checked. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_first
Function.Description: With this function you can return the first element of the array or undefined if the array is empty.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.

Function.Name: array_last
Function.Description: With this function you can return the last element of the array or undefined if the array is empty.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.

Function.Name: array_create_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can create an array of a given size, initialising each element with the provided function.
Function.Parameter: The size of the array to create.
The function to be used for element initialisation. Accepts the following arguments (index) and should return the init value of the element.

Function.Name: array_find_index
Function.Description: With this function you can find the index of the first element that returns true to the given predicate. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The function used to perform the search. Accepts the following arguments (value, index) and should return a boolean.
The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_any
Function.Description: With this function you can check if any of the elements returns true to the given predicate. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The function used to perform the check. Accepts the following arguments (value, index) and should return a boolean.
The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_all
Function.Description: With this function you can check if all of the elements return true to the given predicate. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The function used to perform the check. Accepts the following arguments (value, index) and should return a boolean.
The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_foreach
Function.Description: With this function you can execute a method on all or a range of elements in the array. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The function to be executed for each array entry. Accepts the following arguments (value, index).
The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_reduce
Function.Description: With this function you can traverse the array/range performing a cumulative operation on its elements. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The function to be executed for each array entry. Accepts the following arguments (prev, value, index) and should return a new 'prev'.
The initial value to be used for the previous element. Defaults to array[offset], if ommitted first iteration will be skipped.
The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_copy_while
Function.Description: With this function you can create a new array from elements of the current array while the predicate is matched. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The function to be executed for each array entry. Accepts the following arguments (value, index) and should return a boolean.
The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_filter
Function.Description: With this function you can create a new array with only the elements that return true to the given predicate. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The function to be executed as filter. Accepts the following arguments (value, index) and should return a boolean.
The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_filter_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can mutate an existing array to filter the elements that return true to the given predicate. This function returns the number of filtered elements. The filtered elements will be padded to offset and order by the traversing direction. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The function to be executed as filter. Accepts the following arguments (value, index) and should return a boolean.
The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_map
Function.Description: With this function you can create a new array by mapping the current array elements using the given predicate. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The function to be executed for mapping the values. Accepts the following arguments (value, index) and should return the mapped value.
The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_map_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can mutate an existing array by mapping the element values using the given predicate. This function returns the number of mapped elements. The mapped elements will keep their original position on the array. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The function to be executed for mapping the values. Accepts the following arguments (value, index) and should return the mapped value.
The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_unique
Function.Description: With this function you can create a new array with only unique values. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_unique_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can mutate an existing array with only unique value. This function returns the number of unique elements. The mapped elements will be padded to offset and order by the traversing direction. This function allows a custom range definition and reverse order.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_reverse
Function.Description: With this function you can create a new array with the elements in reverse order. This function allows a custom range definition.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_reverse_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can mutate an existing array reversing the elements order. This function returns the number of reversed elements. This function allows a custom range definition.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the array.
The offset to be used when executing the function. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.
On how many entries should the function be executed. Negative values will traverse the array in reverse order. Defaults to array_length() - 1.

Function.Name: array_concat
Function.Description: With this function you can concatenate two or more arrays into a single one.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the first array.
The variable that holds the second array.
The variable that holds the nth array.

Function.Name: array_union
Function.Description: With this function you can join two or more arrays into a single one, removing the duplicates
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the first array.
The variable that holds the second array.
The variable that holds the nth array.

Function.Name: array_intersection
Function.Description: With this function you can create an array of elements common to all the input arrays, removing duplicates.
Function.Parameter: The variable that holds the first array.
The variable that holds the second array.
The variable that holds the nth array.

Function.Name: bool
Function.Description: This function will attempt to convert a given value into a boolean data type, where the value will be returned as true if it is greater than 0.5 and false otherwise.
Function.Parameter: The value to convert.

Function.Name: instanceof
Function.Description: This function can be used to get the name of the function that was used to create a struct when the struct was created using a constructor function and the new operator. You supply the variable with the struct reference to check and the function will return either a string with the function name or undefined. Note that if you pass the function a struct literal (ie: a struct that was created without using a constructor function) then it will simply return the string "struct". This function can also be used to check if a struct reference is a weak reference or not, in which case the function will return the string "weakref" instead of the name of the function that created the struct for more information, see the function weak_ref_create()).
Function.Parameter: The struct reference to use.

Function.Name: is_instanceof
Function.Description: returns true if "struct" has "constructor_name" as part of its inheritance hierarchy
Function.Parameter: The struct reference to check.
The constructor reference to check against

Function.Name: static_get
Function.Description: returns the static struct for the given struct or function / script, returns undefined if no static struct is set.
Function.Parameter: The struct or Function reference to use.

Function.Name: static_set
Function.Description: sets the static struct on the given struct.
Function.Parameter: The struct reference to set.
The struct to set as the static

Function.Name: int64
Function.Description: This function will attempt to convert a given value into a 64bit integer, where the value must be either a real, a string, an int64, an int32, or a ptr. Anything else will cause the game to crash with an error message. You can check to see if a variable holds an int64 using the function is_int64().
Function.Parameter: The value to convert.

Function.Name: is_array
Function.Description: This function can be used to check and see if a variable holds an array (it will return true) or not (in which case it will return false).
Function.Parameter: The variable to check.

Function.Name: is_bool
Function.Description: This function returns whether a given variable is a boolean (true ior false) or not. In some cases you want to check and see if a variable in GameMaker holds a boolean value, and that's when you would use this function.
Function.Parameter: The argument to check.

Function.Name: is_infinity
Function.Description: This function returns whether a given variable is infinity (an infinite number) or not, returning true if it is, and false if it is not.
Function.Parameter: The argument to check.

Function.Name: is_int32
Function.Description: This function returns whether a given variable is a 32bit integer or not. In some cases you want to check and see what data type a variable holds in GameMaker and that's when you would use this function. It returns true or false depending on whether the value is an int 32 or not.
Function.Parameter: The argument to check.

Function.Name: is_int64
Function.Description: This function returns whether a given variable is a 64bit integer or not. In some cases you want to check and see what data type a variable holds in GameMaker and that's when you would use this function. It returns true or false depending on whether the value is an int64 or not.
Function.Parameter: The argument to check.

Function.Name: is_matrix
Function.Description: This function returns whether a given variable refers to a matrix or not. In some cases you want to check and see what data type a variable holds in GameMaker and that's when you would use this function. It returns true or false depending on whether the value is a matrix or not.
Function.Parameter: The argument to check.

Function.Name: is_method
Function.Description: This function can be used to check and see if a variable is a method variable (it will return true) or not (in which case it will return false).
Function.Parameter: The variable to check.

Function.Name: is_nan
Function.Description: This function returns whether a given variable is NaN (not a number) or not, returning true if it is, and false if it is not.
Function.Parameter: The argument to check.

Function.Name: is_numeric
Function.Description: This function returns whether a given variable is a numeric value (real, int32, int64 or boolean) or not. In some cases you want to check and see if a variable in GameMaker holds any numeric value, and that's when you would use this function. The function will return true if the given input is numeric, and false otherwise.
Function.Parameter: The input to check.

Function.Name: is_ptr
Function.Description: This function returns whether a given variable is a pointer or not. In some cases you want to check and see what data type a variable holds in GameMaker and that's when you would use this function. It returns true or false depending on whether the value is a pointer or not.
Function.Parameter: The argument to check.

Function.Name: is_real
Function.Description: This function returns whether a given variable is a real number (single, double or integer) or not. In some cases you want to check and see if a variable holds a real number, and that's when you would use this function. It does not return the real number but rather true or false, so a value of, for example, "fish" would return false, however a value of 200 would return true.
Function.Parameter: The argument to check.

Function.Name: is_string
Function.Description: This function returns whether a given variable is a string number or not. In some cases you want to check and see if a variable in GameMaker holds a string and not a real and that's when you would use this function. It does not return the string but rather true or false, so a value of, for example, "fish" for n will return true, but a value of 200 for n will return false.
Function.Parameter: The argument to check.

Function.Name: is_struct
Function.Description: This function checks if the supplied value is a struct. It returns true if it is, otherwise it returns false.
Function.Parameter: The value to check.

Function.Name: is_undefined
Function.Description: This function returns whether a given variable is defined or not. In some cases you want to check and see what data type a variable holds in GameMaker and that's when you would use this function. It returns true or false depending on whether the value is defined or not.
Function.Parameter: The argument to check.

Function.Name: is_vec3
Function.Description: In some cases you want to check and see what data type a variable holds in GameMaker and that's when you would use this function. It returns true or false depending on whether the value is a 3 value vector or not.
Function.Parameter: The argument to check.

Function.Name: is_vec4
Function.Description: In some cases you want to check and see what data type a variable holds in GameMaker and that's when you would use this function. It returns true or false depending on whether the value is a 4 value vector or not.
Function.Parameter: The argument to check.

Function.Name: method
Function.Description: With this function you can bind any function that has previously been defined to a given instance or struct, creating a method variable that can be used later. You supply the instance ID to use (it must be an instance that is active and in the room, and can't be an object ID) or a struct reference, as well as the ID of the function that you want to bind. The function will return a method which can be called from the variable it is assigned to (see the code example below). It is worth noting that you can bind built-in functions as well as user defined functions, and you can also supply undefined as the instance/struct argument meaning that the current self scope will be used for the binding.
Function.Parameter: The unique reference or ID value of the struct or instance to use (or undefined for self)
The ID of the function to use

Function.Name: method_get_index
Function.Description: With this function you can retrieve the Script index for the script where the method was defined. If the method was not defined in a script then the function will return -1, otherwise it will return the index value for the script.
Function.Parameter: The method variable to check

Function.Name: method_get_self
Function.Description: With this function you can retrieve the instance ID or struct reference which is the self context used when the method is called. If the variable is not a method then the function will return undefined. Please note that the function may also return the constant pointer_null, in which case the current self is being used at the time of the call.
Function.Parameter: The method variable to check.

Function.Name: ptr
Function.Description: This function will attempt to convert a given value into a pointer data type, where the value must be either a real, a string, an int64, an int32, or a ptr. Anything else will cause the game to crash with an error message.
Function.Parameter: The value to convert.

Function.Name: typeof
Function.Description: This function returns the data type of any given variable as a string. The possible return values are listed in the table below:
Function.Parameter: The variable to get the data type of.

Function.Name: variable_global_exists
Function.Description: With this function you can check whether a global scope variable exists or not. You supply the global variable name to check for as a string (see example code below) and the function will return true if a global variable with the given name exists or false otherwise.
Function.Parameter: The name of the global variable to check for (as a string)

Function.Name: variable_global_get
Function.Description: With this function you can get the value from a given named global variable. You supply the name of the global variable to get the value of as a string (see example code below) and the function will return the value held by the global variable or undefined if the variable does not exist.
Function.Parameter: The name of the global variable to get (as a string)

Function.Name: variable_global_set
Function.Description: With this function you can set the value of a given global variable. You supply the name of the global variable to set the value of as a string (see example code below), and then the value to set (can be any valid data type). If the global variable does not exist already in the game it will be created and then assigned the value.
Function.Parameter: The name of the global variable to set (as a string)
The value to set the global variable to

Function.Name: variable_instance_exists
Function.Description: With this function you can check whether an instance scope variable exists or not. You supply the unique instance ID value (which can be found from the Instance Properties in the room editor, or is returned when you call the function instance_create_layer()) as well as the variable name to check for as a string (see example code below). The function will return true if a variable with the given name exists for the instance and false otherwise.
Function.Parameter: The unique ID value of the instance to check
The name of the variable to check for (as a string)

Function.Name: variable_instance_get
Function.Description: With this function you can get the value from a given named variable. You supply the unique instance ID value (which can be found from the Instance Properties in the room editor, or is returned when you call the function instance_create_layer()) as well as the name of the variable to get the value of as a string (see example code below). The function will return the value held by the variable, or undefined if the variable does not exist.
Function.Parameter: The unique ID value of the instance to use
The name of the variable to get (as a string)

Function.Name: variable_instance_get_names
Function.Description: With this function you can retrieve an array populated with the instance variable names for an instance, or the global variables for a game. When you pass in an instance ID value, each entry in the array will be a string of the variable name that corresponds to an instance scope variable that has been created in the instance. However if you pass in the keyword global, each entry in the array will be a string of the variable name that corresponds to an global scope variable.
Function.Parameter: The unique ID value of the instance to check or the keyword global

Function.Name: variable_instance_names_count
Function.Description: With this function you can find the total number number of variables defined for an instance. You supply the instance ID to check, and the function will return an integer value for the number of variables encountered, or (if no instance of the given ID exists) -1.
Function.Parameter: The unique ID value of the instance to check.

Function.Name: variable_instance_set
Function.Description: With this function you can set the value of a given variable in an instance. You supply the unique instance ID value (which can be found from the Instance Properties in the room editor, or is returned when you call the function instance_create_layer()) as well as the name of the variable to set the value of as a string (see example code below), and then finally the value to set (can be any valid data type). If the variable does not exist already in the instance it will be created and then assigned the value.
Function.Parameter: The unique ID value of the instance to use
The name of the variable to set (as a string)
The value to set the variable to

Function.Name: variable_struct_exists
Function.Description: With this function you can check whether a variable exists within the given struct or not. You supply the struct reference to use as well as the variable name to check for as a string (see example code below). The function will return true if a variable with the given name exists for the struct and false otherwise.
Function.Parameter: The struct reference to check
The name of the struct variable to check for (as a string)

Function.Name: variable_struct_get
Function.Description: With this function you can get the value from a given named variable within a struct. You supply the struct reference as well as the name of the variable to get the value of as a string (see example code below). The function will return the value held by the variable or undefined if the named variable does not exist.
Function.Parameter: The struct reference to use
The name of the variable to get (as a string)

Function.Name: variable_struct_get_names
Function.Description: With this function you can retrieve an array populated with the variable names from a struct. You pass in the struct reference to check, and each entry in the array will be a string of the variable names that the struct contains.
Function.Parameter: The struct reference to check.

Function.Name: variable_struct_names_count
Function.Description: With this function you can find the total number number of variables defined for a struct. You supply the struct ID to check, and the function will return an integer value for the number of variables encountered, or (if no struct of the given ID exists) -1.
Function.Parameter: The unique ID value of the struct to check.

Function.Name: variable_struct_remove
Function.Description: With this function you can remove a variable from a struct. You supply the struct ID to remove the variable from and the string name of the variable to be removed.
Function.Parameter: The struct reference to remove the variable from
The name of the variable to remove (as a string)

Function.Name: variable_struct_set
Function.Description: With this function you can set the value of a given variable in a struct. You supply the struct reference as well as the name of the variable to set the value of as a string (see example code below), and then finally the value to set (can be any valid data type). If the variable does not exist already in the struct it will be created and then assigned the value.
Function.Parameter: The struct reference to set
The name of the variable to set (as a string)
The value to set the variable to

Function.Name: analytics_event
Function.Description: This function will send the specified text to the analytics provider that you have set up through the HTML5 Game Options. This function can be used to create a custom analytic to track something outside of the scope of the provider being used.
Function.Parameter: A string to send to the provider

Function.Name: analytics_event_ext
Function.Description: This function will send the specified text to the analytics provider that you have set up through the HTML5 Game Options. This function can be used to create a custom analytic to track something outside of the scope of the provider being used, and will also accept custom parameter/value pairs, where the parameter is a string and the value a real number. For Google Analytics, you can only add in one extra pair while Flurry will accept up to 7.
Function.Parameter: A string to send to the provider.
The parameter to send (a string).
The value of the parameter (a real number).

Function.Name: browser_input_capture
Function.Description: With this function you can set whether the browser window should capture all input (set it to false) or whether the game should capture the input (set it to true). Note that this function is for use with the HTML5 module only.

Function.Name: clickable_add
Function.Description: With this function you can create a custom, clickable, icon that acts as a "button" outside of the game canvas, but within the browser window itself. The function will return an id value which must be stored in a variable to be used in all further button functions that reference the new icon. This function is very useful to prevent the browser creating a pop-up window when clicking on the button as it is all done through GameMaker itself.
Function.Parameter: The x position within the window.
The y position within the window.
The texture page entry for the sprite to be used.
The URL (website address) to link to, or the script to be run.
This is the target area to open the URL in (see description).
The various parameters for the icon (see description).

Function.Name: clickable_add_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can create a custom, clickable, icon that acts as a "button" outside of the game canvas, but within the browser window itself. The function will return an id value which must be stored in a variable to be used in all further button functions that reference the new icon. This function is very useful to prevent the browser creating a pop-up window when clicking on the button as it is all done through GameMaker itself.
Function.Parameter: The x position within the window.
The y position within the window.
The texture page entry for the sprite to be used.
The URL (website address) to link to, or the script to be run.
This is the target area to open the URL in (see description).
The various parameters for the icon (see description).
The image alpha of the icon (default 1).
The scale of the icon (default 1).

Function.Name: clickable_change
Function.Description: With this function you can change the sprite and position of a clickable icon previously created with clickable_add(). Please note that the position is based on the window, not the canvas, (0,0) position and that the sprite must be referenced directly from the texture page (see: sprite_get_tpe()).
Function.Parameter: The index of the clickable icon to change.
The texture page entry for the sprite to be used.
The new x position within the window.
The new y position within the window.

Function.Name: clickable_change_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can change the sprite and position of a clickable icon previously created with clickable_add(). Bear in mind that the position is based on the window, not the canvas, (0,0) position and that the sprite must be referenced directly from the texture page (see: sprite_get_tpe()). This function also permits you to change the scale of the sprite used (as a multiplier so that 1 is the default, 0.5 would be half and 2 would be double) and the alpha value from 0 (fully transparent) to 1 (fully opaque) for the final icon on the screen.
Function.Parameter: The index of the clickable icon to change.
The texture page entry for the sprite to be used
The new x position within the window.
The new y position within the window.
The scale of the icon (default 1).
The image alpha of the icon (default 1).

Function.Name: clickable_delete
Function.Description: This function must be used to remove a clickable icon previously created with clickable_add() from the game window.
Function.Parameter: Index of the clickable icon to remove.

Function.Name: clickable_exists
Function.Description: This function returns whether a clickable DOM icon has been created with the specified index exists or not. Please note, that the value used for checking must have been initialised previously or else you will get an error causing GameMaker to close.
Function.Parameter: The index of the clickable to check.

Function.Name: clickable_set_style
Function.Description: This function lets you set the CSS style properties for the given button via the key/value pairs in the provided DS Map. You need to have previously created the both the button element (using clickable_add()) and the DS Map and supply the stored indices to each as arguments.
Function.Parameter: The index of the clickable icon to style.
The index of the DS Map to set the style from.

Function.Name: url_get_domain
Function.Description: You can use this to get the domain where your HTML5 game is being played.

Function.Name: url_open
Function.Description: This will open the specified URL on the browser of the chosen target device, or, if you are using the HTML5 module, in the currently open browser.
Function.Parameter: The URL (website address) to link to.

Function.Name: url_open_ext
Function.Description: This will open the specified URL on the browser of the chosen target device, or, if you are using the HTML5 module, in the currently open browser. The "target" parameter that you specify is the same as the standard JavaScript "name" value when you use the open() method, and you should be aware that all but "_self" may result in the browser blocking, or asking the user if they wish to allow it.
Function.Parameter: The URL (website address) to link to.
This is the target area to open the URL in.

Function.Name: url_open_full
Function.Description: This will open the specified URL on the browser of the chosen target device, or, if you are using the HTML5 module, in the currently open browser. The "target" parameter that you specify is the same as the standard JavaScript "name" value when you use the open() method (be aware that all but "_self" may result in the browser blocking, or asking the user if they wish to allow it) and the "options" is the same as the JavaScript "specs" parameter for controlling what properties the new window/tab should display (not all browsers may support all features).
Function.Parameter: The URL (website address) to link to.
This is the target area to open the URL in (see description).
Standard browser options (see description).

Function.Name: randomize
Function.Description: This function sets the seed to a random value. Should you need to keep a consistent value over a number of runs of a game, you should be using random_set_seed(). Please note, that when using the random number functions in GameMaker the initial seed is always the same, as this makes tracing errors and debugging far easier. Should you wish to test with true random, you should call this function at the start of your game. The function will return the new randomised seed value (an unsigned 32bit integer).

Function.Name: dot_product_normalized
Function.Description: The dot product is a value expressing the angular relationship between two vectors and is found by taking two vectors, multiplying them together and then adding the results. The name "dot product" is derived from the centered dot "·" that is often used to designate this operation (the alternative name "scalar product" emphasizes the scalar rather than vector nature of the result).
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the first vector.
The y coordinate of the first vector.
The x coordinate of the second vector.
The y coordinate of the second vector.

Function.Name: dot_product_3d_normalized
Function.Description: The dot product is a value expressing the angular relationship between two vectors and is found by taking two vectors, multiplying them together and then adding the results. The name "dot product" is derived from the centered dot "·" that is often used to designate this operation (the alternative name "scalar product" emphasizes the scalar rather than vector nature of the result).
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the first vector.
The y coordinate of the first vector.
The z coordinate of the first vector.
The x coordinate of the second vector.
The y coordinate of the second vector.
The z coordinate of the second vector.

Function.Name: draw_set_color
Function.Description: With this function you can set the base draw colour for the game. This value will affect all further drawing where appropriate, including fonts, forms, primitives and 3D. If any of those assets are drawn with their own colour value changed, this value will be ignored.
Function.Parameter: The colour to set for drawing.

Function.Name: draw_get_color
Function.Description: This function returns the current draw colour which is used for drawing forms, text, primitives and un-textured 3D models. This can be set with the draw_set_color() function.

Function.Name: merge_color
Function.Description: With this function you can take two colours and then merge them together to make a new colour. The amount of each of the component colours can be defined by changing the "amount" argument, where a value of 0 will return the first colour (col1), a value of 1 will return the second colour (col2) and a value in between will return the corresponding mix. For example, a value of 0.5 will mix the two colours equally. The following image illustrates how this works by merging the colours red and blue together:
Function.Parameter: The first colour to merge
The second colour to merge
How much of each colour should be merged. For example, 0 will return col1, 1 will return col2, and 0.5 would return a merge of both colours equally

Function.Name: make_color_rgb
Function.Description: GameMaker provides this function (as well as others) to permit the user to make their own colours. This particular function takes three component parts, the red, the green and the blue components of the colour that you wish to make. These values are taken as being between 0 and 255 so you can make 16,777,216 (256*256*256) colours with this! Below you can see an image of how these components look when separated:
Function.Parameter: The red component of the colour
The green component of the colour
The blue component of the colour

Function.Name: make_color_hsv
Function.Description: GameMaker provides this function (as well as others) to permit the user to make their own colours. This particular function takes three component parts, the hue, the saturation and the value (also know as "luminosity") to create the colour desired. These values are taken as being between 0 and 255 so you can make 16,777,216 (256*256*256) colours with this! Below you can see an image of how these components look when separated:
Function.Parameter: The hue of the colour
How saturated the colour is
How dark the colour is

Function.Name: color_get_red
Function.Description: This function returns the amount of red used to make the given color, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no red and 255 is all red. The following image illustrates this:
Function.Parameter: The color to check

Function.Name: color_get_green
Function.Description: This function returns the amount of green used to make the given color, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no green and 255 is all green. The following image illustrates this:
Function.Parameter: The color to check

Function.Name: color_get_blue
Function.Description: This function returns the amount of blue used to make the given color, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no blue and 255 is all blue. The following image illustrates this:
Function.Parameter: The color to check

Function.Name: color_get_hue
Function.Description: This function will return the hue of the given color. This is the "pure" color tone which is part of the hue, saturation and value (luminosity) method for defining a color. The following image illustrates how this value corresponds to the HSV scale of color:
Function.Parameter: The color to check

Function.Name: color_get_saturation
Function.Description: This function will return the saturation of the given color. This is the amount of the color tone that is mixed into the final color and is part of the hue, saturation and value (luminosity) method for defining a color. The following image illustrates how this value corresponds to the HSV scale of color:
Function.Parameter: The color to check

Function.Name: color_get_value
Function.Description: This function will return the value (luminosity) of the given color. This is the amount of the "light" that is mixed into the final color and is part of the hue, saturation and value method for defining a color. The following image illustrates how this value corresponds to the HSV scale of color:
Function.Parameter: The colour to check

Function.Name: draw_text_color
Function.Description: This function will draw text in a similar way to draw_text() only now you can choose the colours to use for colouring the text as well as the alpha value, and these new values will be used instead of the base drawing colour and alpha.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the drawn string.
The y coordinate of the drawn string.
The string to draw.
The colour for the top left of the drawn text.
The colour for the top right of the drawn text.
The colour for the bottom right of the drawn text.
The colour for the bottom left of the drawn text.
The alpha for the text.

Function.Name: draw_text_ext_color
Function.Description: This function is a combination of the base draw_text() function with the draw_text_ext() and draw_text_colour() functions, permitting you to define gradient colours for text as well as the line spacing and maximum width per line all together.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the drawn string.
The y coordinate of the drawn string.
The string to draw.
The distance in pixels between lines of text.
The maximum width in pixels of the string before a line break.
The colour for the top left of the drawn text.
The colour for the top right of the drawn text.
The colour for the bottom right of the drawn text.
The colour for the bottom left of the drawn text.
The alpha for the text.

Function.Name: draw_text_transformed_color
Function.Description: This function is a combination of the base draw_text() function with the draw_text_transformed() and draw_text_colour() functions, permitting you to scale and rotate text as well as colour it with a gradient fill and change its alpha value, ignoring the base alpha and colour settings for drawing.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the drawn string.
The y coordinate of the drawn string.
The string to draw.
The horizontal scale.
The vertical scale.
The angle of the text.
The colour for the top left of the drawn text.
The colour for the top right of the drawn text.
The colour for the bottom right of the drawn text.
The colour for the bottom left of the drawn text.
The alpha for the text.

Function.Name: draw_text_ext_transformed_color
Function.Description: This function is a combination of the base draw_text() function with the draw_text_ext(), draw_text_transformed() and draw_text_colour() functions. As such, this is the most general of all functions for drawing text and gives a large amount of flexibility when drawing. Note that the "width" argument is based on a scale of 1, so if the scale is different, this value should be changed proportionally. For example, if the base width for a line break is 300 and you set the scale to 2, then the text will appear wrong, over-running the given width. Instead you should have set the width to 150 to compensate the scaling.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the drawn string.
The y coordinate of the drawn string.
The string to draw.
The distance in pixels between lines of text.
The maximum width in pixels of the string before a line break.
The horizontal scale.
The vertical scale.
The angle of the text.
The colour for the top left of the drawn text.
The colour for the top right of the drawn text.
The colour for the bottom right of the drawn text.
The colour for the bottom left of the drawn text.
The alpha for the text.

Function.Name: draw_point_color
Function.Description: With this function you can draw a single pixel anywhere on the screen with a colour that you define. The colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour().
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the point.
The y coordinate of the point.
The colour of the point.

Function.Name: draw_line_color
Function.Description: With this function you can draw a 1 pixel wide line with the colour blended between colour 1 at the first point and colour 2 at the second point. The colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour(). Please note that the line being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the start of the line.
The y coordinate of the start of the line.
The x coordinate of the end of the line.
The y coordinate of the end of the line.
The colour of the start of the line.
The colour of the end of the line.

Function.Name: draw_line_width_color
Function.Description: With this function you can draw a line of a specific width with the colour blended between colour 1 at the first point and colour 2 at the second point. The colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour(). Please note that the line being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the start of the line.
The y coordinate of the start of the line.
The x coordinate of the end of the line.
The y coordinate of the end of the line.
The width in pixels of the line.
The colour of the start of the line.
The colour of the end of the line.

Function.Name: draw_rectangle_color
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rectangle or a filled rectangle by defining an area where the (x1,y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2,y2) position is the bottom right corner. If it is filled you can define the individual colours for each corner point and if these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left of the rectangle.
The y coordinate of the top of the rectangle.
The x coordinate of the right of the rectangle.
The y coordinate of the bottom of the rectangle.
The colour of the top left corner.
The colour of the top right corner.
The colour of the bottom right corner.
The colour of the bottom left corner.
Whether the rectangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

Function.Name: draw_roundrect_color
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rounded rectangle or a filled rounded rectangle where the (x1,y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2,y2) position is the bottom right corner. If it is filled you can define the individual colours for the centre and the edges, and if these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()).You can define how precise the drawing of the corners is with the function draw_set_circle_precision(), but the corners are always drawn with a fixed radius. Should you need to change the corner radius you should use the function draw_roundrect_colour_ext(). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left of the rounded rectangle.
The y coordinate of the top of the rounded rectangle.
The x coordinate of the right of the rounded rectangle.
The y coordinate of the bottom of the rounded rectangle.
The center colour.
The outside edge colour.
Whether the rectangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

Function.Name: draw_roundrect_color_ext
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rounded rectangle or a filled rounded rectangle where the (x1,y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2,y2) position is the bottom right corner. If the rectangle is filled, then the colour arguments will be used to generate a colour gradient from the centre to the edges, where colour 1 is the centre colour and colour 2 the edge colour. You must also supply radius values for the x and y axis (in pixels) and the corners will be rounded by these amounts. You can define how precise the drawing of the corners is with the function draw_set_circle_precision(). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left of the rounded rectangle.
The y coordinate of the top of the rounded rectangle.
The x coordinate of the right of the rounded rectangle.
The y coordinate of the bottom of the rounded rectangle.
The radius of the curve along the x axis from the rectangle corners.
The radius of the curve along the y axis from the rectangle corners.
The center colour.
The outside edge colour.
Whether the rectangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

Function.Name: draw_triangle_color
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a triangle or a filled triangle. If it is filled you can define the individual colours for each corner point and if these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()).
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the triangle's first corner.
The y coordinate of the triangle's first corner.
The x coordinate of the triangle's second corner.
The y coordinate of the triangle's second corner.
The x coordinate of the triangle's third corner.
The y coordinate of the triangle's third corner.
The colour of the first corner.
The colour of the second corner.
The colour of the third corner.
Whether the triangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

Function.Name: draw_circle_color
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a circle or a filled circle, and if it is filled you can define the interior and exterior fill colours. If these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other and the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour(). You can define how precise the drawing is with the function draw_set_circle_precision().
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the center of the circle.
The y coordinate of the center of the circle.
The radius (distance from center to edge) of the circle in pixels.
The colour at the center of the circle.
The colour at the edge of the circle.
Whether the circle is an outline (true) or not (false). If true, col1 is irrelevant.

Function.Name: draw_ellipse_color
Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of an ellipse or a filled ellipse by defining a rectangular area that will then have the ellipse created to fit. If it is filled you can define the interior and exterior fill colours. If these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()). You can define how precise the drawing is with the function draw_set_circle_precision().
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the left of the ellipse.
The y coordinate of the top of the ellipse.
The x coordinate of the right of the ellipse.
The y coordinate of the bottom of the ellipse.
The colour of the center.
The colour of the edge.
Whether the ellipse is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

Function.Name: draw_vertex_color
Function.Description: This function defines the position of a vertex for a primitive, with its own colour and alpha setting. The final look of the primitive will depend on the primitive type chosen to draw and the order with which you add the vertexes to it (see draw_primitive_begin() for more information) and the vertexes with different colours and alphas will blend smoothly from one to the other. To end and draw the primitive you must call draw_primitive_end().
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the vertex.
The y coordinate of the vertex.
The colour to draw this vertex with.
The alpha to draw this vertex with (0-1).

Function.Name: draw_vertex_texture_color
Function.Description: This function defines the position of a textured vertex for a primitive. The final look of the primitive will depend on the primitive type chosen to draw (See draw_primitive_begin() for more information), the order with which you add the vertices to it, the position of the start and end points that you give for the texture sample and the colour and alpha values that you have set. To maintain the texture appearance while changing only the alpha, a value of -1 (or c_white) may be used for the colour argument. To end and draw the primitive you must call draw_primitive_end().
Function.Parameter: The x coordinate of the vertex.
The y coordinate of the vertex.
The x coordinate within the texture.
The y coordinate within the texture.
The colour to blend with the texture at this vertex (-1 or c_white for no blending).
The alpha to draw this vertex with (0-1).

Function.Name: window_set_color
Function.Description: This function can set the background colour of the game window. This colour represents that which will be used for those areas of the game window that are not occupied by any views. The following image illustrates this:
Function.Parameter: The colour to set the region.

Function.Name: window_get_color
Function.Description: This function returns the background colour of the game window. This colour represents that which will be used for those areas of the game window that are not occupied by any views. The following image illustrates this:

Function.Name: part_type_color1
Function.Description: This function is used to set a particle type to be a single colour for the total duration of the lifetime of each individual particle.
Function.Parameter: The index of the particle type to change.
The single colour to make the particle type.

Function.Name: part_type_color2
Function.Description: This function can be used to set a two colour gradient for each particle created of the given type. The first colour is that which all particles will start with, and the second colour is the one on which the particle will end with, and a smooth gradient change will occur to the colour over the particles lifetime from one colour to the other.
Function.Parameter: The index of the particle type to change.
The colour the particle will start at.
The colour the particle will end at.

Function.Name: part_type_color3
Function.Description: This function can be used to set a three colour gradient for each particle created of the given type. The first colour is that which all particles will start with, and the second colour is the one that will be blended to half way through its lifetime and the third colour is the one with which the particle will end with. A smooth gradient change will occur through the colours over the particles lifetime from one colour to the other.
Function.Parameter: The index of the particle type to change.
The colour the particle will start at.
The colour the particle will be halfway through its lifespan.
The colour the particle will end at.

Function.Name: part_type_color_mix
Function.Description: With this function you can set the given particle type to be a random blend of two colours.
Function.Parameter: The index of the particle type to change.
The first colour the blend will take from.
The second colour the blend will take from.

Function.Name: part_type_color_rgb
Function.Description: With this function you can set the mix of red, green and blue colours for all particles created of the given type. You supply a minimum value and a maximum value for each of the three components and the particles created will have a random colour based on the given range of parameters. All values must be between 0 and 255.
Function.Parameter: The index of the particle type to change.
The minimum the final colour's red component can be.
The maximum the final colour's red component can be.
The minimum the final colour's green component can be.
The maximum the final colour's green component can be.
The minimum the final colour's blue component can be.
The maximum the final colour's blue component can be.

Function.Name: part_type_color_hsv
Function.Description: With this function you can set a hue, saturation and value range for all particles of the given type. You supply a minimum value and a maximum value for each of the three components and the particles created will have a random colour based on the given range of parameters. In this way you can create particles of the same hue but different saturations, or of different hues but the same value (luminosity) etc... All values must be between 0 and 255.
Function.Parameter: The index of the particle type to change.
The minimum the final colour's hue component can be.
The maximum the final colour's hue component can be.
The minimum the final colour's saturation component can be.
The maximum the final colour's saturation component can be.
The minimum the final colour's value component can be.
The maximum the final colour's value component can be.

Function.Name: part_particles_create_color
Function.Description: This function is ideal for those effects that do not require any of the functionality offered by particle emitters (for example, to create smoke from a missile, or a simple explosion effect) as it permits you to quickly and easily create particles at any position in the game room. You can also colour the particles "on the fly" as they are created with this function, and this colour will over-ride the predefined colour of the particle, but it does not blend this colour over the particles lifetime. Note that you must have created the particle system and the particle type previously for this function to be used.
Function.Parameter: The index of the particle system.
The x coordinate of where to create the particles.
The y coordinate of where to create the particles.
The index (type) of the particles to be created.
The colour blending for the particles.
The number of particles to create.

Function.Name: os_request_permission
Function.Parameter: More optional permissions

Function.Name: display_set_gui_maximise
Function.Parameter: The horizontal scaling factor (use -1 to reset to default).
The vertical scaling factor (use -1 to reset to default).
The x offset position for drawing.
The y offset position for drawing.

Function.Name: display_set_gui_maximize
Function.Parameter: The horizontal scaling factor (use -1 to reset to default).
The vertical scaling factor (use -1 to reset to default).
The x offset position for drawing.
The y offset position for drawing.

Function.Name: gpu_set_colorwriteenable
Function.Description: With this function you can switch on or off the colour channels and the alpha channel for all further drawing. For example, you can use this function to create alpha-channel only surfaces (switch off the RGB writing before using the surface), or to create special effects while drawing to the screen. The default value for each of the components is true, and can be supplied as either four unique arguments or as a 4 element 1D array with the following elements in it which will be either true (enabled) or false (disabled):
Function.Parameter: Enable/disable the red channel
Enable/disable the green channel
Enable/disable the blue channel
Enable/disable the alpha channel

Function.Name: gpu_get_colorwriteenable
Function.Description: This function can be used to retrieve the current colour write-enable values. The function returns a 4 element 1D array with the following elements in it which will be either true (enabled) or false (disabled). By default all colour writing is set to true:

Function.Name: gamepad_set_color
Function.Description: This function can be used to set the colour of the LEDs within a PlayStation controller. You specify the device slot to set, and then give a colour, which can be any of the colour constants or a colour value created using the specific colour functions or a HEX value(like $FFFFFFF).
Function.Parameter: Which gamepad device "slot" to set.
The color to use.

Function.Name: shader_set_uniform_i_array
Function.Parameter: The handle of the shader constant to set.
A previously initialised array of integer values.

Function.Name: vertex_format_add_color
Function.Description: Tell GameMaker to accept colour data as part of the new vertex format being created.

Function.Name: vertex_color
Function.Description: If your defined vertex format takes a colour value you can use this function to add that data to the vertex being defined for the current primitive. The function needs a buffer to store the data in and will take either a colour constant, or a hex value (using the standard GameMaker format of BGR, eg: $FF0000 for blue) as well as an alpha value from 0 (transparent) to 1 (fully opaque).
Function.Parameter: The buffer to write the information to.
The colour for this vertex (can be a constant or a hex value).
The alpha value for the vertex (from 0 to 1).

Function.Name: skeleton_attachment_create_color
Function.Description: When you create you skeletal animation sprite, you can assign attachment slots and attachments to go in them. These are simply images (sprites) that are separate from the animation but when attached will move along with the bone they are attached to. Normally you would assign these attachments in your animation program (Spine), but with this function you can create your own at run-time using a sprite asset from your game. the function requires that you give the attachment a name (as a string) and then set the sprite_index and image_index to use, as well as the x and y origin (which can be different to that defined by the sprite in the sprite properties), and you can also set any transforms that you wish to be applied to the image when attached, as well as the colour to be blended with the image and it's alpha (transparency) value. If the attachment was successfully created the function will return 1 and if it was not (you supplied an invalid sprite index, or the base sprite is not a Spine sprite) then it will return -1.
Function.Parameter: The name (as a string) of the attachment to create.
The sprite_index to get the attachment image from.
The image_index to get the attachment image from.
The x origin for the image being used.
The y origin for the image being used.
The horizontal scaling of the image, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...
The vertical scaling of the image, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...
The rotation of the image: 0 = normal, 90 = turned 90° counter-clockwise etc.
The colour value to use (A constant, integer or hex value).
The alpha value to use (from 0 to 1).

Function.Name: skeleton_slot_color_set
Function.Description: With this function you can set an attachment slot colour and alpha so all sprites attached to it will be drawn with these blend values. Keep in mind that the instance sprite can have a blend colour and alpha setting (image_blend and image_alpha), as can the attachment (see the function skeleton_attachment_create_colour()), and so the final colour and alpha that the assigned attachment sprite for the slot will have will be a composite of all these values.
Function.Parameter: The slot name to set, a string
The colour to set, either an integer, a constant, or a hex value.
The alpha to set from 0 to 1.

Function.Name: skeleton_slot_color_get
